abstract.p: Frank Reissman letter comments on Sally L Satel's July 14 Op-Ed article on controlled drinking for problem drinkers

block.p: Re ''Learning to Say 'I've Had Enough,' '' by Sally L. Satel (Op-Ed, July 14):
Re ''Learning to Say 'I've Had Enough,' '' by Sally L. Satel (Op-Ed, July 14):

I was a heavy drinker for 25 years. About eight years ago, my doctor discovered that I was diabetic and suggested that I cut down. I said, No, I'll just quit. It was easy for me to quit drinking, but in the process I discovered that I had a more serious addiction to sugary foods and drinks, which are also dangerous for my health.

This situation led me to formulate a theory of addiction: there are simple addicts and complex addicts. In the case of a simple addict, there may be physical cravings and withdrawal symptoms but no deep psychological dependence. But in complex addictions, the substance has a psychological hold on the person.

Sweets are like this for me. Here, I use abstinence; it restores my control and reduces the addiction to a simpler physical level, which I can handle. But abstinence is not necessarily an end in itself.
The writer is executive director of Selfhelpweb.org, a national self-help clearinghouse.
